thread.title: Delhi Bids Adieu to NorthEast Festival 2015 shouting “One More”
thread.title_full: Delhi Bids Adieu to NorthEast Festival 2015 shouting “One More”

author: Bishwajit Aribam
title: Delhi Bids Adieu to NorthEast Festival 2015 shouting “One More”
text: Comment Photo: Bishwajit Aribam After showcasing a solid package of North East’s art and culture for three consecutive days, the biggest North East festival out of north-east concludes with some famous numbers from Bollywood singer and heartthrob of the region, Jubeen Garg at IGNCA in Janpath on October 18. With tourism as key focus- promoting incredible destinations, the 3rd edition of the festival put on display an elaborate range of programmes such as painting, photography, fashion shows, cartoon exhibition, handloom- handicrafts stalls, dance and musical performances. The event was attended by more than three lakh people, which include , policymakers of the country, senior ministers in Union Cabinet, Chief Ministers of various North Eastern States, top North East icons, top bureaucrats, intellectuals, students, and tour operators, among others. The final day of the festival stressed more attention to Majauli, which is the largest river island in the World. Visitors from different parts of India were shown a short audio visual presentation about Majauli’s heritage, resources and alarming concern of soil erosion. Majauli is located in the banks of Brahmaputra River. More than 40 musical bans- Boomarang, Purple Fusion, Abiogenesis, Traffic Jam, SKD, Parikrama,The Local Train, Girish & The Chronicles, Anaya Brahma enthralled the crowd during the the third installment of the festival. The event also showcased 30 dance forms while around 50 stalls are packed with products ranged from tea, spice, flower vase, sandals, table lamps, floral bags, traditional clothes, decorative flowers and other products sourced from the region. Apart from music and cultural dance shows, agro and horti exhibition, exhibition of various tribes, display of achievements of freedom fighters and traditional sports were also put up in the event. Meetings with stakeholders about investment opportunities in the North-East was also organised. The festival, which was inaugurated by Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on 16th September, featured signature cuisines from the North-east states. He appreciated the initiative of festival and assured the North-east community people in Delhi full security and support. Happy visitors tasted different kinds of food which include delicious bamboo shoot, pork and duck – flavoured with world famous Bhut Jolokia. The fourth edition is expected to come in the city next year around the same time to rock the city yet again. */
